articles.headline: To Conquer Wind Power, China Writes the Rules
articles.snippet: Competing for China’s lucrative business means playing by house rules that are often stacked in Beijing’s favor.
articles.abstract: Competing for China’s lucrative business means playing by house rules that are often stacked in Beijing’s favor.
articles.lead_paragraph: TIANJIN, China  Judging by the din at its factory here one recent day, the Spanish company Gamesa may seem to be a thriving player in the Chinese wind energy industry it helped create.

articles.headline: Fed Goes Ahead With Bond Plan
articles.snippet: Fed policy makers stuck with the $600 billion bond-buying plan, despite widespread criticism and the increase in the yield on Treasury notes.
articles.abstract: Fed policy makers stuck with the $600 billion bond-buying plan, despite widespread criticism and the increase in the yield on Treasury notes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve, batting away unusually fierce criticisms, forged ahead on Tuesday with its effort to prop up the economic recovery by buying $600 billion in Treasury bonds.

articles.headline: Save the Children Breaks With Soda Tax Effort
articles.snippet: Save the Children said a halt in support of efforts to tax soda was unrelated to a grant it wants from Coca-Cola.
articles.abstract: Save the Children said a halt in support of efforts to tax soda was unrelated to a grant it wants from Coca-Cola.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the last year, Save the Children emerged as a leader in the push to tax sweetened soft drinks as a way to combat childhood obesity. The nonprofit group supported soda tax campaigns in Mississippi, New Mexico, Washington State, Philadelphia and the District of Columbia.

articles.headline: Opposition to Health Law Is Steeped in Tradition
articles.snippet: Resistance to the expansion of the social safety net stems from tension between two competing traditions.
articles.abstract: Resistance to the expansion of the social safety net stems from tension between two competing traditions.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We are against forcing all citizens, regardless of need, into a compulsory government program,” said one prominent critic of the new health care law. It is socialized medicine, he argued. If it stands, he said, “one of these days, you and I are going to spend our sunset years telling our children, and our children’s children, what it once was like in America when men were free.”

articles.headline: Politics Enables Mexican Fugitive to Defang a Law
articles.snippet: The status of a legislator elected 15 months before he vanished from public view comes with a perk: immunity.
articles.abstract: The status of a legislator elected 15 months before he vanished from public view comes with a perk: immunity.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY  Despite being a federal fugitive, accused of laundering millions of dollars for one of Mexico’s most ruthless drug cartels, Julio César Godoy says he simply walked into the national legislature here unnoticed in September, right past the cordon of federal police officers watching the building.

articles.headline: Intelligence Reports Offer Dim View of Afghan War
articles.snippet: As President Obama prepares a strategy review, two reports say there is a limited chance of success.
articles.abstract: As President Obama prepares a strategy review, two reports say there is a limited chance of success.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  As President Obama prepares to release a review of American strategy in Afghanistan that will claim progress in the nine-year-old war there, two new classified intelligence reports offer a more negative assessment and say there is a limited chance of success unless Pakistan hunts down insurgents operating from havens on its Afghan border.

articles.headline: U.S. Called Vulnerable to Rare Earth Shortages
articles.snippet: It could take 15 years to break American dependence on Chinese supplies of critical manufacturing minerals.
articles.abstract: It could take 15 years to break American dependence on Chinese supplies of critical manufacturing minerals.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The United States is too reliant on China for minerals crucial to new clean energy technologies, making the American economy vulnerable to shortages of materials needed for a range of green products — from compact fluorescent light bulbs to electric cars to giant wind turbines.

articles.headline: E-Readers With Color Open Door for Pictures
articles.snippet: Publishers are capitalizing on the iPad and the Nook Color by producing illustrated e-books, particularly for children.
articles.abstract: Publishers are capitalizing on the iPad and the Nook Color by producing illustrated e-books, particularly for children.
articles.lead_paragraph: Millions of consumers have embraced black-and-white e-readers like the Kindle for reading simple novels or nonfiction  but books with color illustrations have generally remained better read in print.
